question: The difference between subsystems and modules are:
answers: Subsystems can independently comprise the business logic by itself while modules can't.

question: Software quality attributes that we care about during software architecture are:
Software architecture concerns itself with both estimation and quality but not partitioning.
Which of the following is considered the most difficult in the software development process?
What is a Requirements Specification?
Based on the NASA statistics on budget and schedule overrun vs. time spent on requirements process, what is the recommended amount of time to spend on the requirements stage?
answers: 5-10% of the total time spent on the project

question: Which of the following matches the terms to the correct definition?
answers: Requirements - user needs in user language; Specification - solution properties designed to solve problem

question: Which of these is a user requirement?
answers: Allow the user to post a message to Facebook

question: Which of the following is NOT an example of a non-functional requirement.
answers: The user shall be able to select the course number.

question: What element(s) of the WRSPM model belong in the environment (including the overlap between environment and system)?
Which of these is proper definition of software architecture?
answers: partitioning large systems into smaller ones that can be created separately, have individual business value, and can be easily integrated

question: Which of the following models is best suited for a system with significant shared data that needs to be shared across a variety of components or sub-systems, somewhat like global variables, but with better data integrity?
Which of the following models is best suited for a system that includes several subsets of functionality that are used in more than one area of the system?

Which of the following models is best suited for a system that benefits from the separation of complexity and processing between work which can be done locally and that which should be completed on a shared, remote service?
Which of the following would be considered a sub-system, rather than a module?
answers: A set of classes which generates reports

question: Where does software design fit in the traditional waterfall software development lifecycle?
Which of the following is NOT an aspect of software design
The ability to use a built-in function of a programming language to generate a random number is an example of which of the following?
Analyzing the extent to which other modules must change when a module is modified is an example of which of the following?
When all of the responsibilities of a module are easily classified as being strongly related, this is an example of high what?
Which of the following is most preferred?
answers: Allowing one module to affect the program flow of another via the use of a state message (message coupling)

question: Which of the following is LEAST desirable?
answers: including functionality which occurs around the same time

question: Which of the following are necessary before proper testing?
answers: inputs, expected output, and an oracle

question: Which of the following is a mistake made by the developer?
Which of the following is an example of validation?
answers: software is well-received by the user

question: In your current project, you have access to some intern development resources, which are not currently operating at full capacity. You also know that the testing timeline will be truncated, due to delays in critical-path module development. Which strategy should you employ?
answers: Utilize the intern resources to design and develop drivers and stubs, while work continues on critical-path module development

question: When is testing complete?
answers: When you run out of time

question: Which of the following is an example of black-box testing?
answers: Developing test cases based on typical user behavior

question: What are some of the challenges with the Waterfall methods that prompted the software industry to come up with alternatives like Agile? (select 2)
answers: It is difficult to predict user/customer needs.
Incorrect interpretations of requirements by developers go undetected for a long time. During user acceptance tests, these issues are discovered but it is very late.

question: Which of the following statements aligns with the value "Working software over comprehensive documentation” of Agile manifesto? (select any 2)
answers: Value delivering software over writing documentation.
If documentation is absolutely essential then create it.

question: Which one of the following statements/situations/conversations align with an Agile mindset?
answers: Manager: “The customer is suggesting another change in feature X which is complete as per specification. They agree that it was built as we agreed upon but it lacks some functionality and will result in user frustration. Should we implement the change or not?” Developer: “Yes, if it does not fulfill user needs, we should make the change."

question: Which of the following is TRUE about lean startup? (select all that apply)
answers: Lean Startup concepts recommends to go through Build-Measure-Learn cycles as fast as you can.
In Lean Startup, you try to validate/invalidate your assumptions (crucial for the success of your product) as fast as you can.

question: Which of following is valid on a Kanban Board? (select any 2)
answers: WIP limit for Step X is 5. Step X is divided into "Doing" and "Done." Number of items in "Doing" column is 3, and number of items in "Done" column is 1. One of the item in previous step is done and developer wants to move that item to Step X

WIP limit for Step X is 3. Step X is divided into "Doing" and "Done." Number of items in "Doing" column is 2, and number of items in "Done" column is 1. One of the items in the previous step is done and developer wants to move that item to Step X

question: Which of the following Framework/process model supports Agile Mindset? (select all that apply)

A software development team just started using Kanban. They had the following columns with WIP limit of 3 for each column on their Kanban board from left to right: Backlog(3), Analysis(3), Development(3), Testing(3), Deployment There are currently 3 items in Testing (3 items being tested) Similarly, there are 3 items in Development column (2 items are in development and 1 item is done being developed) One of the developers does not have anything to work on so the manager wants to add one more item to the development column so the developer looking for work can work on it. Which one of the following would be a valid action in this situation? (Select any 3)
answers: Team should get together and discuss if we should increase the WIP limit of the development column as we have more developers and it will be smoother flow if WIP limit of the Development column is increased.
Manager should ask the developer waiting for work to help the testers so that they can finish one of the items from their column and move it to Deployment column.

The manager should ask the testers to move one of the items of the Test column temporarily to the Deployment column so that we can move items from the Development column. Later, we can move items back from the Deployment column to the Testing column.

question: In Scrum, when is the sprint backlog created?
In Scrum, how is Product Backlog Arranged?
answers: Most important items at the top, least important items at the bottom.

question: Which of the following is an mistake in code which is found in code review?
Which of the following is TRUE about Scrum? (Select all that apply)
answers: Scrum has fixed time-boxed development cycles called sprints.

question: Which of the following statements align with the value "Working software over comprehensive documentation” of Agile manifesto? (select any 2)
answers: If documentation is absolutely essential then create it.
Value delivering software over writing documentation.

question: Which of the following are true about Agile Manifesto? (select any 2)
answers: The Agile Manifesto consists of 4 values and 12 principles.
The Agile Manifesto is work in progress and we are continuing to learn.

question: Which one of the following statements/situations/conversations align with an agile mindset?
answers: Manager: “The customer is suggesting another change in feature X which is complete according to the specification. They agree that it was built as we agreed upon but it lacks some functionality and will result in user frustration. Should we implement the change or not?” Developer: “Yes, if it does not fulfill user needs, we should make the change."

question: Why is it difficult to predict user needs and requirements? (select any 3)
answers: Sometime the market shifts from time when the requirements were originally defined.

question: Which of the following statements align with following Agile Principle: "Deliver working software frequently, from a couple of weeks to a couple of months, with a preference for the shorter timescale"
answers: We should frequently deliver software in some environment (not necessarily to production always) to gather user/client feedback

question: Which of the following align with this principle: " Working software is the primary measure of progress."
answers: If a team has delivered 5 features out of 10 features (or stories), team has made progress (they are more than 0% done)

question: In which of the following situations, would you NOT recommend using an agile process?
answers: For a project where change is not expected. requirements are well known, and the solution is both well known and repeatable.

question: Which of the following is true for agile projects?
answers: An agile methodology may help a team to go to market early by delivering with limited functionality.

question: One of the core principles of agile is to "Embrace Change". This makes architecting and designing the system challenging since you don't know all of the requirements upfront. Thus, you have to be prepared to make architecture and design changes. To effectively embrace change, agile teams must learn how to keep the cost of change low. From the options below, select the ones that can help mitigate this challenge. (Select 3)
answers: Keep the code clean and continuously improve/refactor the design as needed. Don't delay these changes for later.
Automated Regression testing provides faster feedback which helps you detect defects quickly. This in turn, gives you confidence to make changes.
Keep design simple and just build what is required. It is easier to change a simple design than to update a complicated design.

question: Which of the following is true for a typical agile project? (select 2)
answers: The team talks about the high-level software architecture / design as well as their approach for building software (the release plan) before directly jumping into coding.
If required, the team may need to plan and conduct training, etc. for users before launching the system.

question: What is true about user stories in Agile Software Development? (Select any 3)
answers: User stories are tokens for conversations.
Stories can be written at different levels and can be refined and split into smaller stories as you move from vague idea to implemented software.
User stories are used to plan, design, describe, build, and validate your product.

question: What are some of the benefits of writing acceptance tests for a story? (select 4)
answers: They help the product owner (who is writing the story) think through the user needs.
They help you write tests cases for the story.
They help build a common understanding between team members.
They can potentially help you split stories, if required.

question: What is wrong with the following story? (Select any 2) "As a product owner, I want a list of highly-rated restaurants on the brochure."
answers: It doesn't specify the value of the story (the "why" is missing).
The user who benefits from this story is missing (the "who" is missing).

question: What is wrong with following user story? (Select any 2) "I want the software to be easy to use."
How is gathering user needs / requirements different on an agile project? (select any 3)
answers: At any given time, the level of detail may be different for different parts of the software.
The agile way supports progressive refinement---defining the right level of detail at the right time.
Agile encourages conversations as a key method for building a shared understanding.

question: What are some of the activities that happen during a User Story Writing Workshop? (Select any 4)
answers: User role analysis and defining personas
Sometimes, you keep it free-form for people to write stories and later group them by theme.
To generate stories, one of the options is to start from the top down or bottom up.
Everybody silently writes user stories around a theme

question: Which of the following are true about the Story Mapping technique? (select 3)
answers: It is a user-centric approach where we map out the system from a user's perspective.
The horizontal axis (moving from left to right) in a story map represents time.
The vertical axis (moving from top to bottom) in a story map represents rough priority.

question: Due to an unpredictable market event, the Product Owner (PO) asked the team to complete the next release in 6 weeks. Assuming the backlog in Table 2 is up to date and prioritized from highest to lowest, the Product Owner wants you to estimate what can be done in next 6 weeks. Describe 1) what can be done, 2) what might be done, and 3) what will not be done. The velocity range to be used for the release planning is 15-22. The team works in 2 week iteration. Table 2: Prioritized Product Backlog Story Title Estimate (in ideal days) Story 1 5 Story 2 5 Story 3 8 Story 4 3 Story 5 5 Story 6 5 Story 7 3 Story 8 5 Story 9 8 Story 10 8 Story 11 3 Story 12 3 Story 13 3 Story 14 5 Story 15 8 Story 16 3 Story 17 5 Story 18 5 Story 19 8 Story 20 8
answers: Most likely: Story 1 to Story 8; Might Be Done: Story 9 to Story 13; Not likely: Rest of the stories

question: What is true about planning with an agile mindset? (Select any 2)
answers: Plan just enough, just in time.

question: What do we mean by Velocity in agile terms?
answers: It is calculated at the team level and represents how much work a team can get done in an iteration.

question: Which of the following is true about Scrum?
answers: Burn-down and Burn-up charts help the team track the progress of the current sprint.
In the daily stand-up, everybody talks about what they worked on, what they are planning to work on, and any impediments they have.

question: Which of the following is TRUE about Scrum? (Select two)
answers: Scrum has fixed, time-boxed development cycles called sprints.

question: You are a developer on a scrum team. Your scrum master invited you to attend a sprint planning meeting. Which of following activities would you expect in that meeting?
answers: The team will select the stories to work on for next iteration (sprint).
Either during the meeting or afterwards, developers create tasks to further solidify what work needs to be done and make final a work commitment for the sprint.
The product owner (or equivalent) shares the top priority stories for the sprint.
The developers/testers ask questions to understand the stories.
The developers/testers provide a high-level estimate for stories.

question: During sprint planning, you are in the process of calculating team members capacity for an iteration. Which of the following activities should be EXCLUDED from the committed capacity of the team member?
answers: Team member taking vacation / days off / Paid time off (PTO)

question: What should happen in the sprint review meeting? (select any 3)
answers: What happened during the Sprint is reported.
A potentially shippable product increment is demonstrated live.
Feedback is gathered from stakeholders resulting in additional items added to the product backlog.

question: The CEO asks a team member to do some work outside the goals of the current sprint in progress. What should the team member do?
answers: Inform the product owner so he can work with the CEO and if it is still necessary to get this work done in current sprint, it should be discussed with in the team.

question: When is a sprint complete?
answers: When the sprint duration ends. For example, if sprints are 2 weeks long, then the sprint is complete at the end of those 2 weeks.

question: Which of the following are goals of the daily stand-up meeting?
answers: Set team direction and synchronize the day’s activities.

question: Which of following is true about Sprint Reviews?
answers: Individual team members should be encouraged to demo the work they did.

question: Which of the following statements are true about the Sprint Retrospective? (select all that apply)
answers: Team members should avoid blaming (finger pointing) other team members in the retrospective.
It is important to follow up on action items the team decided to work on.

question: Which XP practice prescribes that "the code [always be] written by two programmers at one machine"?
Which of the following are primary practices prescribed by XP?
Which of the following is the meaning of XP practice "Whole Team"?
answers: All the skills necessary to deliver the software product should be present on the team.

question: If an XP team cannot provide an estimate for a story, what should they do to gain a better understanding of the story?
answers: Create a spike story---a new story under which the team will do some research or other work to gain a better understanding of the original story.

question: According to XP's principles, what should you do when a story's acceptance test fails?
answers: Create a bug report so it can be fixed.

question: What activities occur as part of XP's "Weekly Planning" practice?
According to the concept of "Whole Team", which of the following statements are true?
answers: If the team finds out that they need a particular skill in the team, they can add a person with that skill to the team.
It is not recommended for a team member to be part of multiple teams.
All of the skills the team needs to be successful should be in the team.

question: An XP team is getting feedback more frequently than they can handle. What should they do?
answers: Slow down the frequency of feedback.

question: Which of the following is the right sequence when developing software using the XP practice of Test First Programming?
answers: Write a test Make sure the test fails Write enough code so the test passes Refactor as necessary

question: Which of the following statements are true about the XP value of "Simplicity"?
answers: Select the simplest design that could possibly work.

question: In Lean software development, how can amplifying learning occur? (Select all that apply)
answers: The developers make different solutions, each with the exact same features.

question: How can waste arise in software development? (Select all that apply)
answers: Developers work on rarely used product features.
There are product defects found late in the development.

question: In Lean software development, what does the principle of "defer commitment" mean?
answers: Decisions are made after having enough information from considering the alternatives.

question: In Lean software development, what does the principle of "deliver fast" mean? (select 2 that apply)
answers: A simpler version of software product (an MVP - Minimum Viable Product) is developed first to reach the market rapidly.
Iterations are short, so feedback is frequent, and product evolution is rapid.

question: Which of the following align with the lean principle of "build quality in"? (select 2 that apply)
answers: The developers refactor the source code to be simpler and easier to modify.
The developers apply practices to avoid or quickly catch errors while making the software product.

question: In Lean software development, what does "optimize the whole" mean? (Select all the apply)
answers: Rather than trying to optimize one part, look at the whole system for optimization opportunities.
The ability of a system to achieve its purpose depends on how well the parts work together, not just how well they perform individually.

question: Which of the following tools can help you find waste in a process?
What are some of the tools to amplify learning? (Select all that apply)
How do you deliver fast (i.e reduce cycle time) without compromising the quality?
answers: Minimize the number of items in-process.

question: "The Last Responsible Moment" is a tool for which Lean Software Principle?
Lean helps increase productivity by:
answers: Reducing the amount of useless activity that our resources (the team members) are currently burdened with.

question: Which practices waste time during software development? (Choose two)
answers: Weekly meetings that are held whether or not they are needed.

question: The 5 "Whys" to be considered during a Root Cause Analysis are...?
answers: Why, Why, Why, Why and Why

question: What is the purpose of the Lean tool 'Kaizen'?
answers: An improvement activity to create more value and remove waste.

question: Which of the following can be used to do 5 Whys analysis?
In Kanban, a developer pulls the next item to work on from the:

You are a developer on a team using a Kanban board to manage flow. You work on Step X within the process and it just so happens that you are looking for more work. The Kanban board is set up as follows: Step X has a WIP limit of 3. Step X is divided into "Doing" and "Done." The number of items in the "Doing" column is 2. The number of items in the "Done" column is 1. Without violating the rules of the Kanban board, what should you do? Select all that apply.
answers: Help the group (that picks work from the following column) finish their work so they can pull an item from the "Done" column of Step X. That will allow you to pick an item from the previous step.
Talk to the team about adjusting the WIP limit because increasing the WIP limit will create a better flow of work.

question: Which of the following statements are true about Value Stream Mapping? Select all that apply.
answers: Cycle Time is the total time taken for Value Stream.
Value-added activities are activities that add value from the customer perspective.

question: What is the formula to calculate the Process Cycle Efficiency?
What is the main goal of the Build-Measure-Learn Cycle?
answers: To go through the build-measure-learn cycle as fast as possible.

question: What do we mean by Validated Learning?
answers: Validating the assumptions by conducting an experiment and collecting data.

question: Which of the following are principles of Lean startup? Select all that apply.
Which of the following are true about Lean Startup? Select two.
answers: It is based on going through the Build-Measure-Learn cycle as fast as you can.
It relies on actual data rather than gut feelings to validate assumptions or ideas.

question: Why are traditional management principles ill-suited to the world of startups?
answers: Because startups face chaos and uncertainty.

question: When a startup 'pivots', what is it doing?
answers: Employing a revised strategy in an attempt to achieve its vision.

question: According to Ries, which of the following adjectives describes good startup metrics? Select all that apply.
Which of the following are levels of Pirate Metrics? Select all that apply.
Which of the following are true about Pivot or Persevere? Select two.
answers: Customer segment pivot: The product hypothesis is partially confirmed; it solves the right problem but for a different customer than originally anticipated.
Platform pivot: A change from an application to a platform or vice versa.

question: How do Vanity metrics prevent/inhibit pivoting?
answers: Vanity metrics allow entrepreneurs to draw incorrect conclusions. Based on these metrics, they assume that the product is going in the right direction when it really isn't.

question: What are three ways that a past customer can drive sustainable growth?
answers: As side advertising due to usage of the product

question: What are the characteristics of "Early Adopters"?
answers: Early adopters are actively seeking a solution to the problem your product solves.
Early adopters will give you their time and honest feedback.

question: What are leap-of-faith assumptions?
answers: Assumptions that are the riskiest elements of a startup plan.

question: Which of these attributes are favored by Lean startup? Select two.
Who is an "Intrapreneur" ?
answers: A manager who promotes innovations within the company.

question: Which of the following are true about Design Thinking? Select 2.
answers: It recommends that a cross-functional team work together in the design thinking process.
It is a process for creative problem solving.

question: In design thinking, what are two of the main reasons to empathize with users?
answers: To prevent team member bias from impacting their understanding of the problem and influencing the solution.
To discover the real problem to be solved.

question: Design thinking results in innovation by integrating which three things?
What are the two dimensions for categorizing assumptions?
answers: Probability that it will be wrong
Impact on our solution if it is wrong

question: What are the two dimensions for categorizing tests?
answers: Quality of data collected from the test

question: The logical (intended) dependency is that observer depends on subject.

Up until now, the great state of Foo has held a lottery to help fund education in the state. The corporation tasked with the drawing of these numbers (the non-televised ones) is XYZ Numerical Tasking. You are the technical lead for the system which handles the drawings for the state's lotteries. One of your developers, with a mathematical tilt, comes to you with a proposal: change how the random numbers are generated. He suggests that the generation of random numbers could be better. NASA has released a random number generator which has been proven to be better than the one used by the company. He suggests that you make the change. One of your more senior developers notes that using the new generator will require a change. He suggests that the team connect the existing lotto system, as seen in Figure 1, to the new generator (Figure 2) using the Facade pattern. Figure 1 Figure 2 Facade, which seeks to simplify complex processes for a client by providing a API which hides the complicated calls/work needed, doesn't seem to fit. What pattern does?

Within the Custodial Management System, there are are a variety of items that are being watched at any given time. Certain items can receive notifications that a response is needed immediately (rather than just tracking whether the regular upkeep has been done that week/month/etc.). These items may then need one of several possible actions: rapid cleaning, bodily fluid containment and/or removal, addressing traction/slip-danger, urgent repair, etc. Each of these actions fit the same profile (action) but not necessarily the same steps. Which pattern would fit well as a solution to this systems needs?

Early in our proof-of-concept work on the new game we are building, we effectively hard-coded the game to ask the user what action to take next, for both players. In this case, both users are tied into a single account, so that we can play against ourselves while we build out the game. Now, however, we want to add a new player type to the system, EasyDifficultyBot. While the "player" actions fit the same high-level format for both humans and our AI, the details of making it happen vary pretty widely. In order to allow for this change, we want to make use of a pattern that will allow this kind of expansion while minimizing changes to the existing code. What pattern would be best here?
Consider the statement "In the Strategy pattern, the context should hold references to the ConcreteStrategies." Under what circumstances would this be true? Select all that apply.
answers: When the context is tasked with deciding which strategy to use

question: In the Observer pattern, one difficulty is that the Subject cannot pass an instance of itself to the Observer being updated, due to circular dependencies.
Once a class has been had an Adapter pattern solution applied, it cannot be adapted again.
Factories are no longer useful when you apply the Strategy Pattern to a family of algorithms.
Observer is an implementation of the Dependency Inversion principle.
Strategy Pattern helps maintain the Open/Closed Principle.

While calculating LCOM4, we ignore constructors and destructors. Constructors and destructors frequently set and clear all variables in the class, making all methods connected through these variables, which increases cohesion artificially. LCOM4 = 1 indicates a cohesive class, which is the "good" class. LCOM4 >= 2 indicates a problem. The class should be split into so many smaller classes. Using a debugger can find all defects in code.
What is created to allow a compiler to temporarily stop processing code that is being executed to allow for the developer to see current state?
Commits should happen only at the end of a daily coding session.
Only one line of code should change per commit.
Commit messages are only helpful to you at the time you make them.
Branching aids developers seeking to work on the same code simultaneously.
Project materials are stored in a remote repository through the WebHook functionality.
Compilers perform static analysis.
Static analysis can only be performed while code is being executed.

1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 class Airplane { private: int customerCapacity; string _Manufacturer; public: Airplane (int capacity, string manufacturer); int load_Customers(Customer *); }; Which of the following are style errors for the code on Line 2?
The goal of test selection is to find the maximum number of tests that can be successfully run.
Randomly testing is the poorest form of testing.
The developer of the code is the best person to test that code.
Manually created tests can use randomly selected inputs to maximize defect finding.
Code coverage includes statement coverage, ensuring all code statements are executed at least once by at least one test case and all tests pass.
Requirements testing is difficult because the tests can't be created until the code is written, which is quite far into the development process.
Program testing helps find defects, but testing cannot prove there are no bugs.
A test case is a set of inputs written to try and "break the code", i.e. find a defect.
Test obligations come from Structural Analysis, that is, from the code itself.
Tests which meet the code coverage criteria can still be poor tests.
New processes/reports are able to be added to the Jenkins Pipeline through plug-ins.
Continuous Integration alerts to submitting developer of build or test failure, but cannot remove the code committed.
Continuous Integration is a subset of the capabilities in a Continuous Delivery pipeline.
Pushing code to production without the need for developer action is one of the primary benefits of Continuous Delivery.
The difference between Continuous Delivery and Continuous Deployment is whether the deployment of code to production is manual or automated, respectively.
Canary is a system of alerts to developers based on build, test, release and/or deployment. The alerts are similar to "tweets" as on Twitter, hence the similarity of the names.
Since the goal is for every test to pass, tests should only include inputs which will result in successful operation/behavior when executed on correct code.
The developer should first run the tests before adding anything new, as in to ensure that all tests passed before adding any new tests or code.
Continuous Delivery is an update to the Blue-Green Deployment paradigm.
Statement coverage is the strongest form of code coverage, which is why it is required for many FAA and FDA regulated software projects.
Which of the following are true about requirements and specifications? (Choose all that apply)
answers: Requirements shall be written in the user's language; system specifications shall be written in the system language.
Requirements are for users; specifications are for developers.

question: The following are the requirements and specifications of an online banking service. Which of the following can be categorized as (user) requirements? Select two.
answers: The user shall be able to check the current balance of the checking accounts that he/she own.
A user shall be able to use the online banking system securely.

question: The following are requirements and specifications of an online banking service. Which of the following can be categorized as system specifications? Select two.
answers: At the time a query is made to check the current balance of a checking account, the owner of the checking account shall be logged in.
Activate a login session when a user logs in, and maintain the session for 60 minutes unless the user who logged in has been inactive for more than 120 seconds.

question: A constraint to only use Microsoft Project during the system development is a non-functional requirement.
Which of the following are non-functional requirements:

Looking at the difference between user requirements and system specifications in the ATM example, we know that swiping the card and prompting for a PIN are requirements, while reading the card details and a 4-digit PIN are specifications.
WRSPM stands for:
answers: World, Requirement, Specification, Program and Machine.

question: The purpose of the WRSPM model is to ensure that:
A subsystem in an architecture must:
Partitioning of a large system into smaller subsystems helps the buy-or-build decision because we can examine each subsystem and reason about possible buy-or-build options for each.
A good software architecture is important because:
answers: It helps organize the workforce and resources.
It allows for parallelization in development.

question: A UNIX program where the output of one program is the input of another, is an example of which of the software architecture models below:
An online banking system is best modeled by:
What element(s) of the WRSPM model belong in the interface (i.e. the overlap between environment and system)?
A vehicle identification and tracking system, where each moving vehicle is tracked and monitored through a shared program, is best modeled by:
Software design is the process of transforming the stated problem into a ready-to-use implementation.
Abstract solutions do not require extensive domain knowledge and effectively reduce the costs during the software design phase.
It is often advised that abstract solutions do not provide optimization details regarding the implementation.
When it comes to software design, it is always best to follow a solution that is widely popular in the industry

While a solution coming from software design does not include implementation details, there are still common cases where pseudocode may be provided to correctly capture the sense of a complex algorithm.
Check all that apply: The four aspects of modularity are...
Which of the four aspects of modularity is defined as: How well modules work together.
Which of the four aspects of modularity can be described as: Abstracting away implementation details.
Which of the four aspects of modularity can be described as: How well a module meets a single well-defined goal.
Which of the four aspects of modularity can be described as: Containment of constructs and concepts within a module.
Three goals of ______ can be described as (1) Decomposability, (2) Composability, and (3) Ease of Understanding.
You have a sort function that provides no details on which sorting algorithm is used. This is an example of which aspect of modularity?
Choose the most accurate answer: Low coupling aids in...
answers: ensuring that changes don't cross boundaries of modules.

question: Which of the following statements about coupling are true?
The goal in low coupling is to ensure that changes don't cross the boundaries of modules.
The three types of tight coupling are:
Module A relies directly on local data of module B. This is an example of what type of coupling?
Modules A and B both rely on global data or a global variable. This is an example of what type of coupling?
Modules rely on externally imposed format (or protocol or interface). This is an example of what type of coupling?
The two types of medium coupling are:
Module A controls the logical flow of module B. This is an example of what type of coupling?
Module A and B both rely on the same composite data structure. This is an example of what type of coupling?
The three types of loose coupling are:
Modules only share parameters. This is an example of what type of coupling?
The loosest type of coupling; components only communicate through parameters or message passing. This is an example of what type of coupling?
A benefit to using ______ is that you know if your data is corrupted, then it must have been corrupted by the module.
Choose the most accurate answer: Cohesion describes...
answers: how well everything within a module fits together.

question: Which of the following statements about cohesion is true?
The goal in real-life software development is to aim for object and functional cohesion and anything less than this should be justified.
The four types of weak cohesion are:
Parts of modules are together in the same file. This is an example of what type of cohesion?
Different pieces of code are activated at the same time. This is an example of what type of cohesion?
One piece of code runs after the other. This is an example of what type of cohesion?
Components do similar but separate things. This is an example of what type of cohesion?
The two types of medium cohesion are:
All elements of a component operate on the same input or produce the same output. This is an example of what type of cohesion?
One component's output provides the input to another component. This is an example of what type of cohesion?
The two types of strong cohesion are:
Each operation in a module is provided to allow object attributes to be modified or inspected. This is an example of what type of cohesion?
Every part of a component is necessary for a single well-defined behavior. This is an example of what type of cohesion?
True or False: inheritance strengthens cohesion.
Why should you program when you are alert?
Which of the following are examples of 'Write code for people not computers'? Select three.
answers: In your comments, explain WHY the code does what it does.
Let your code (variable names, function names, etc.) explain HOW it does what it does.

question: Fill in the blank. Write ____, _____, and _____ before writing functional code.
If you write the same code more than once...
answers: Put that code into a method.

question: True or False: Every method can be written without side effects.
Deployment occurs in the end stage of active development.
Product deployment should encapsulate three main focus areas. What are they?
answers: Plan for recovery in case of failure

question: Concerns to address in your deployment plan include:
A rollback is the reversal of actions completed during deployment with the intent to never revert a system back to its previous working state.
What are some reasons why you would need a rollback plan? Select two.
answers: Fixing the problem ends up taking longer than the window allows.

question: Deployment without a rollback plan should occasionally occur. Especially when the installation involves deleting files.
The three cutover strategies are...
If you need to have a cutover strategy where the replacement machine is ready for a full setup and install, then you would choose which of the following cutover strategies?
If you need to have a cutover strategy where the replacement services are ready for the redirection of data with no installation, then you would choose which of the following cutover strategies?
If you need to have a cutover strategy where the replacement machine is running and ready for installation, then you would choose which of the following cutover strategies?
There is no difference between load balancing and hot failover.
Test data represents possible inputs that are provided to the _____ for the purposes of testing.
answers: both the system and the oracle

question: The oracle uses information provided from test cases to decide the correctness of the software under test
Test cases are composed of _______
Manual oracles are sufficient and effective for the majority of real-world applications
Choose the correct True-False pair: An error is the manifestation of a failure. A failure is the manifestation of an error.
It is possible for errors to remain undiscovered as long as the erroneous ________ is never used
Software testing can be used to prove the absense of failures in a module, but not the absense of faults
In waterfall method, you get your product in one big bang deployment
Sashimi model may help decrease the time duration of the project by
Which of the following are true for the V-model? Select two.
answers: Testing-related activities are started earlier in the process.

question: In predictive models, change during the development is expected.
In which model might you end up building something different than what you originally planned?
What are the BENEFITS of the Sashimi Model? Select two.
answers: It can support creating a learning prototype early
It can help shorten development time

question: Which of the following is true for the V-model? Select two.
answers: The V-model is useful in cases where there is ambiguity in requirements and early validation would be useful.

question: Which of the following is true for Incremental Models? Select three.
answers: If deploying an increment to actual users can benefit the organization, using an incremental model is a potential candidate to consider.
You can overlap building of one increment with another
Incremental models may result in rework

question: Which of the following is true for the Waterfall model, V-model and Sashimi model? Select two.
answers: In these models, we assume that we know requirements really well

In these models, the cost of change depends on how late we find out about the change. If a problem requiring a change is found during the implementation phase, it will be more expensive to fix than one found during the design phase.

question: Which model is the best model to use in all situations?
In the Unified Process, all requirements work is done upfront and no requirements work is done in the construction phase.
What are some of the activities that happen in the elaboration phase of the Unified Process? Select two.
answers: Validate system architecture by building executable architecture baseline

question: Which of the following activities happen in Step 2 of the Spiral Model? Select two.
Select the four basic steps followed in each cycle of the Spiral Model.
Which of the following are true for the Unified Processes and its variants? Select two.
answers: Agile Unified Process and Open Unified Process are lighter versions of the "Unified Process".
Enterprise Unified Process adds additional practices on top of the Unified Process and Rational Unified Process.

question: What are some of the challenges with Waterfall methods that prompted the software industry to come up with alternatives like Agile? Select three.
answers: Wrong implementation goes undetected for a long time.

Integration issues between different components of the software go undetected for a long time. During the testing phase, when all the components are integrated, these issues are discovered but it is very late in the process.

question: What are the four Agile values according to the Agile Manifesto?
answers: People and Interaction over Processes and Tools.
Responding to Change over Following a Plan

question: Which of the following statements align with the value "Working software over comprehensive documentation” of the Agile manifesto?
answers: Create documentation when it provides value.

question: Which of the following is true about the Agile Manifesto? Select two.
answers: The Agile Manifesto consists of 4 values and 12 principles.
The Agile Manifesto is a work in progress and we are continuing to learn.

question: Why is it difficult to predict user needs and requirements? Select three.
answers: Sometimes the market shifts from the time when the requirements were originally defined.

question: Which of the following are official rituals/meetings/practices in Scrum?
Which of these are core properties of Kanban?
Which of the following are TRUE about Lean Startup? Select two.
answers: In Lean Startup, you try to validate/invalidate your assumptions (crucial for the success of your product) as fast as you can.
Lean Startup concepts recommend to go through Build-Measure-Learn cycles as fast as you can.

question: Which of the following is true about product and sprint backlogs? Select two.
answers: A sprint backlog is created during the sprint planning meeting.
The product backlog is a prioritized backlog with highest priority items on the top.

question: Which of the following is true for adaptive models? (Select any two)
answers: You may end-up building something different than what you originally thought

question: A team divided the application they were building into 4 parts and planning to build one part at a time. To build each part, they are planning to go through the steps of requirements, design, implementation, test, and deployment. Also, they are planning to complete each part fully with high fidelity. By fidelity we mean the completeness of the features implemented in each part. Based on this information, what type of model do you suggest they use for their software development process?

A team is working on a problem where the requirements are well known but they are short on time. They prefer to start the design phase when some of the requirements have been defined. Similarly, they want to start coding when the design for part of the system is ready. What model will best fit their needs?

In the incremental model variation where you do requirements and design for all of the application once and then just increment on implementation, testing, and deployment, are you making the process more suitable for a predictive or adaptive situation?
Which of following is NOT true about incremental and iterative models?
answers: An incremental model is one where you can build each part of the system individually but you release all at once.

question: Which of the following is NOT true for the Waterfall model, V-model and Sashimi model?
answers: These models will be a good model to be used by a startup implement a new idea that is new to market

question: In the Unified Process, what does the milestone of "Lifecycle Architecture" mean?
answers: Agreement among the stakeholders about the technical approach.

question: Which of the following is true for the Unified Process? (select any 3)
answers: It is a framework and not a specific model.

question: Select situations listed below where you would NOT use the Unified Process framework.
answers: Very small, simple project where the problem and solution are well known.

question: Which of the following is NOT true for Spiral Model?
answers: You always have to perform all the steps mentioned in the Spiral Model diagram

question: Which of the following is true about Scrum? Select two.
answers: In daily stand-up, everybody talks about what they worked, what they are planning to work on and share any impediments they have.
Burndown and Burnup chart help teams track the progress of the current sprint.

question: Which of the following is NOT the benefits of the Unified Process?
What are some of the challenges with waterfall methods that prompted the software industry to come up with alternatives like agile? Select three.
answers: It is difficult to predict user/customer needs

Integration issues between different components of the software go undetected for a long time. During the testing phase, when all the components are integrated, these issues are discovered but it is very late in the process.
Incorrect interpretations of requirements by developers go undetected for a long time. During user acceptance tests, these issues are discovered but it is very late.

question: What are the four values of the Agile Manifesto?
answers: People and Interaction Over Processes and tools
Responding to Change Over Following a plan

question: Which Agile Value does the following principle align with: "Build projects around motivated individuals, give them the environment and support they need and trust them to get the job done."
answers: Individuals and Interaction Over Process and Tools

question: Which of the following align with the agile principle: "Business people and developers work together daily throughout the project."
answers: Since agile methodologies do not recommend writing all detailed requirements upfront, it is really important to support greater collaboration between business people and developers so that they can build a shared understanding of what needs to be built.

question: What are some of the benefits organizations have seen from using agile methods? Select five.
The agile principle of "Deliver working software frequently" helps with which of the following challenges of predictive model? Select two.
What new challenges does agile bring? Select two.
answers: Very uncomfortable for leaders because of unpredictable journey

question: What are some of the tactics / concepts you can use to implement agile mindset? Choose two.
answers: To keep the cost of change down, use engineering practices like automated tests, continuous integration, incremental design
Build in small bite-sized chunks. These chunks could represent both iterative and incremental approach

question: If a developer says "because we are agile, we don't need to do any discussion or upfront design", is he/she truly representing what agile means
answers: No, agile does not mean start coding right away.

question: When applying agile, we don't need to do any release planning. We only plan for a week.
What of the following are the qualities of good user story as mentioned in the INVEST model? Choose three.
answers: Independent: Dependencies among stories should be minimized
Valuable: Stories should be valuable to user
Testable: Once the story is implemented, we should be able to test that it is done

question: What issues do you see in following story? As a grocery buyer, I want to see different food items in different colors: red for meats, brown for grains, green for vegetables so that i can identify food items by type.
answers: This story breaks the quality of negotiable.

question: What are the 3 Cs of user stories?
What are some of the key parts of a user story? Choose four.
answers: Who is it for? What does the user want to do? Why does the user want to do that?

question: Which of the following statements are true about "Spike" stories? Choose three.
answers: It is recommended that these stories have well defined acceptance criteria so that team knows what is expected at the end of exploration.
They can be used for knowledge acquisition.

question: The goal of a story writing workshop is to:
answers: Write as many user stories as possible under the themes identified.

question: What are some of the valid ways to handle non-functional requirements in agile development? Select two.
answers: Create specific stories that outline the non-functional needs with clear acceptance criteria.
Add non-functional requirements to the definition of done for all stories.

question: Which of the following are true about story writing workshops? Select two.
answers: A story writing workshop can take anywhere between a few hours to a few days.
The whole team (including the product owner, the scrum master, and the development team) participates in the story writing workshop.

question: What are some of the ways a story map can help software development? (Select any four)
answers: It helps plan releases and work.
It helps communicate user needs with the stakeholders and get feedback.
It builds a shared understanding among team members.

question: What are some of the activities you expect to see in a story mapping exercise? Select three.
answers: Find gaps in the story map by walking through the user experience (as expressed in the activities/tasks) aloud.
Find variations in the paths the user can take through the system.

question: What are the characteristics of good product backlog? (Select any 4)
Who estimates the effort to complete a product backlog item (a user story)?
answers: The scrum development team after clarifying the requirement.

question: What is true about Agile Estimation techniques? Select two.
answers: They estimate effort and not duration.

question: Which of the following estimates represents concept of relative sizing? Select three.
answers: Story A is bigger than Story B. Story C is smaller than Story A.
Story A is 1 apple, Story B is 5 apples, and Story C is 10 apples
Story A will take half the time Story B will take. Story C will take double the time Story A will take.

question: What is true about the planning poker estimation technique? Select three.
answers: Everyone involved in development has to participate in estimation.
It supports the concept of shared estimates.

question: Which of the following observations are true about Card Sorting? Select two.
answers: It is very useful for estimating a large number of stories.
This technique benefits from using relative sizing.

question: What is true about estimation using Ideal Days? Select two.
answers: It has a potential issue of "My ideal days are not your ideal days".
It is very natural for a new team member to understand.

question: Calculate the velocity range a team should use to select work for next iteration based on their past velocities (see chart below). The team uses the last 5 iterations to estimate their velocity. Use format "from-to" to specify the answer (e.g., 0-100). No spaces before/after the dash. Table 1: The velocity of previous iterations Iteration Story points completed 1 14 2 18 3 23 4 17 5 15 6 21 7 22 8 20

A team was doing release planning and they decided that the next release will include all stories from Story 1 to Story 11 (see table 2 below). The velocity range to be used for the release planning is 15-22. The team works in a 2 week iteration. It costs about $50,000 per iteration to fund the entire team. Calculate the estimated duration for next release. Additionally, how much will this release cost? Table 2: Prioritized Product Backlog Story Title Estimate (in ideal days) Story 1 5 Story 2 5 Story 3 8 Story 4 3 Story 5 5 Story 6 5 Story 7 3 Story 8 5 Story 9 8 Story 10 8 Story 11 3 Story 12 3 Story 13 3 Story 14 5 Story 15 8 Story 16 3 Story 17 5 Story 18 5 Story 19 8 Story 20 8
Select scenarios below where the team used the correct approach to handle special cases of team velocity.
answers: To forecast velocity for first iteration, 1) the team builds deeper understanding of few stories from the backlog 2) From the understood stories, they select stories they feel they can get done in one sprint. 3) The sum the estimates of the selected stories is the team's forecasted velocity.
One of the team members is taking a couple days off in next iteration, but the team didn't adjust its velocity to reflect that.

question: Which of the following methods can help you track a release? (select any 2)
answers: A cumulative flow diagram for a release

question: Which of the following are official rituals/meetings/practices in scrum? Select four.
What are the three roles in Scrum?
Who prioritizes the work in Scrum?
What artifacts are defined as part of Scrum framework? Select any 3.
In Scrum, how is the Product Backlog arranged?
answers: Most important items at the top, least important items at the bottom.

question: In which agile artifact are the customer needs captured?
What is usually plotted on the x-axis of the Sprint Burndown Chart?
What is a Sprint Burndown Chart?
answers: A chart showing the trend of work remaining across time in a sprint.

question: Your team is planning out the next sprint. You've chosen to fill the sprint by taking stories in priority order from the product backlog and stopping when you reach the first story that won't fit in the sprint. Based on following details, which stories should the team commit to for a sprint? Table 1: Prioritized story with estimated story points and total estimate in hrs of tasks for that story. Story Story Points Total of Tasks Estimates Story 1 5 16 hrs Story 2 8 16 hrs Story 3 5 24 hrs Story 4 3 16 hrs Story 5 13 32 hrs Story 6 8 26 hrs Story 7 5 8 hrs Story 8 8 15 hrs Story 9 5 12 hrs Table 2: Capacity of Team members for given sprint Name # days available Hours / day Capacity (hrs) You compute this John 3 4-5 Matt 5 2-3 Sally 5 4-5 Ram 5 2-3
During sprint execution, when are new tasks added to the sprint?
answers: As soon as possible after they are identified, unless they reflect a scope change in the sprint goals.

question: Who should attend the sprint retrospective?
How long should the Daily Standup be?
Which of the following are discussed in a sprint retrospective? Select three.
answers: New action items / What can we do better?

question: Which of the following are 5 Lean principles? (Not the 7 principles of Lean software development)
In terms of "Lean", what is the best description of Waste?
answers: Waste is the usage of any resource during the process, which are not recognized by the customer as adding value to the product or service they receive.

question: Lean techniques define "Value" from the perspective of who?
Which of these are core properties of Kanban? (Select all that apply)
Which of following is valid on a Kanban Board? Select two.
answers: The WIP limit for Step X is 3. Step X is divided into "Doing" and "Done". The number of items in the "Doing" column is 2, and the number of items in the "Done" column is 1.

The WIP limit for Step X is 5. Step X is divided into "Doing" and "Done". The number of items in the "Doing" column is 3, and the number of items in the "Done" column is 1. One of the items in the previous step is done and the developers want to move that item to Step X.

question: A software development team just started using Kanban. They had the following columns on their Kanban board, in order from left to right: Backlog, Analysis, Development, Testing, Deployment. Each column has a WIP limit of 3. There are currently 3 items in testing (3 items being tested). Similarly, there are 3 items in the development column (2 items that are in development and 1 item is done with its development). One of the developers does not have anything to work on, so the manager wants to add one more item to the development column so the developer looking for work can work on it. Which of the following are valid next actions in this situation? Select all that apply.
answers: The team should get together and discuss if they should add another tester to the test team so this bottleneck can be resolved quickly.
The manager should ask the developer waiting for work to help the testers so that they can finish one of the items in their column and move it to the deployment column.
The manager should ask the deployment team if a done item in the testing column can be deployed so there is space to move an item from development to testing.
